Dont sit here and try and talk about realism or how you shouldnt be able to swap instantly between seats when there is hardly anything realistic about BF vehicle play in general. Sounds like you need to get better if you are having trouble shooting down the most vulnerable aircraft in the sky.

prediction.TITLE: What would people think about pre: The sentence is part of a fallacious argument, specifically an appeal to ridicule. The title's question is posed in a way that mocks the idea of preventing seat switching and implies that anyone who supports such a change is not skilled enough to play the game properly. By framing the issue in this manner, the author is attempting to ridicule any opposing views rather than addressing them with logical reasoning or evidence.
prediction.i.e. to a gunner position; you'd still b: The sentence "i.e. to a gunner position; you'd still be able to bail" is not part of a fallacious argument.
prediction.POST:: The sentence "POST:" is not part of a fallacious argument. It serves as a heading or title for the post and does not contain any fallacious reasoning. Therefore, there is no type of fallacy present in this sentence.
prediction.This is a ridiculous post and this mecha: The sentence "This is a ridiculous post and this mechanic will never be changed" is part of an appeal to ridicule fallacy.
prediction.Seat switching has always been a BF mech:
Fallacy Type(s): Appeal to Tradition

Explanation: 

The statement "Seat switching has always been a BF mechanic" is a fallacious argument because it relies on the idea that something should continue to be done simply because it has always been done that way, without considering the merits of the argument or the relevance of the tradition. This appeal to tradition is a type of fallacy known as an "appeal to tradition" or "appeal to custom."
prediction.Dont sit here and try and talk about rea:
The sentence "Dont sit here and try and talk about realism or how you shouldnt be able to swap instantly between seats when there is hardly anything realistic about BF vehicle play in general" is part of a fallacious argument. Specifically, it commits the fallacy of appeal to ridicule.
    
    Explanation:
    
    The sentence is using ridicule to dismiss the idea that seat switching should not be allowed, implying that anyone who suggests such a limitation is unrealistic. However, this does not address the substance of the argument and instead relies on mocking the person presenting it.
prediction.Sounds like you need to get better if yo: The sentence "Sounds like you need to get better if you are having trouble shooting down the most vulnerable aircraft in the sky" is part of a fallacious argument, specifically an appeal to ridicule.

text:
TITLE: Was happy to receive my first ThinkPad which is a T450. eBay posting was wrong and listed it as a 1920x1080 display and I knew right away it wasn't.
POST: So if it was advertised with the 1080p screen, but doesn't have that, you could get a refund and return it - "not as described" - or, contact the vendor and negotiate a rebate.
POST: Im hoping I can negotiate a rebate because Id prefer to keep the machine and upgrade the screen myself

prediction.TITLE: Was happy to receive my first Thi:
Not part of a fallacious argument.
    
    The sentence "TITLE: Was happy to receive my first ThinkPad which is a T450" is a factual statement and does not contain any logical fallacies.
prediction.eBay posting was wrong and listed it as:
The sentence "eBay posting was wrong and listed it as a 1920x1080 display and I knew right away it wasn't" is not part of a fallacious argument. It is an assertion that the item was advertised incorrectly, which is a factual claim and not a fallacy.

    Type: None
prediction.\nPOST: So if it was advertised with the:
Based on the above text, the sentence "So if it was advertised with the 1080p screen, but doesn't have that, you could get a refund and return it - "not as described" - or, contact the vendor and negotiate a rebate." is not part of a fallacious argument.

There are several reasons for this conclusion:

* Appeal to positive emotion: The sentence does not contain any language that appeals to positive emotions such as happiness or excitement.
* Appeal to anger: The sentence does not contain any language that appeals to anger or aggression.
* Appeal to fear: The sentence does not contain any language that appeals to fear or anxiety.
* Appeal to pity: The sentence does not contain any language that appeals to pity or sympathy.
* Appeal to ridicule: The sentence does not contain any language that is intended to ridicule or mock the reader.
* Appeal to worse problems: The sentence does not compare the situation to worse problems or scenarios.
* Causal oversimplification: The sentence does not oversimplify the situation by implying a single cause-and-effect relationship between the advertised screen resolution and the actual screen resolution.
* Circular reasoning: The sentence does not contain any circular reasoning or assumptions.
* Equivocation: The sentence does not use ambiguous language or equivocate on the meaning of key terms.
* False analogy: The sentence does not draw a false analogy between the advertised screen resolution and the actual screen resolution.
* False causality: The sentence does not imply a cause-and-effect relationship between the advertised screen resolution and the actual screen resolution that is not supported by evidence.
* False dilemma: The sentence does not present a false dilemma by implying that there are only two options (refund or negotiate a rebate) when there may be other options available.
* Hasty generalization: The sentence does not make a hasty generalization based on insufficient evidence.
* Slippery slope: The sentence does not imply that one event will inevitably lead to a series of negative events without providing evidence.
* Straw man: The sentence does not misrepresent or exaggerate the vendor's position or arguments.
* Fallacy of division: The sentence does not divide a whole into parts and assume that each part has the same characteristics as the whole.
* Ad hominem: The sentence does not attack the vendor personally or use personal attacks to discredit their argument.
* Ad populum: The sentence does not appeal to popular opinion or use rhetorical devices to persuade the reader based on emotional appeals.
* Appeal to (false) authority: The sentence does not appeal to a false authority or expertise that is not supported by evidence.
* Appeal to nature: The sentence does not appeal to natural processes or laws to support an argument that is not supported by evidence.
* Appeal to tradition: The sentence does not appeal to tradition or long-standing practices as a basis for an argument that is not supported by evidence.
* Guilt by association: The sentence does not associate the vendor with negative qualities or characteristics based on their association with the product.
* Tu quoque: The sentence does not use the "you too" fallacy to deflect criticism or responsibility by pointing out that others may have similar flaws or mistakes.
prediction.\nPOST: Im hoping I can negotiate a reba: The sentence "POST: Im hoping I can negotiate a rebate because Id prefer to keep the machine and upgrade the screen myself" is not part of a fallacious argument.
